data.e: AJAX stands for Asynchronous JavaScript And XML, enabling background HTTP requests without reloading the page.

data.q: Which object was traditionally used to make AJAX requests before Fetch API?
data.e: XMLHttpRequest was the traditional way to make asynchronous HTTP requests in browsers.

data.q: Which API provides a modern promise-based way to make HTTP requests?
data.e: The Fetch API provides a modern, promise-based interface for making HTTP requests.

o: A Promise resolving to a Response object
data.e: fetch() returns a Promise that resolves to a Response object.

data.q: Which method is used to parse a JSON response from fetch?
data.e: response.json() parses the response body as JSON and returns a Promise.

data.q: Which HTTP method is typically used to retrieve data?
data.e: GET is the standard HTTP method used to retrieve data from a server.

data.q: How are headers passed in a fetch request?
data.e: Custom headers are passed using the headers option in the fetch configuration object.

data.q: Which option is used to send JSON data in a POST request using fetch?
data.e: The body option is used to send data, often JSON-stringified, in a fetch request.

data.q: What does fetch NOT reject the Promise for?
data.e: fetch does not reject the Promise for HTTP error status codes; these must be checked manually via response.ok.

data.q: Which property is commonly used to check if a fetch response was successful?
data.e: response.ok is a boolean indicating whether the HTTP status code is in the 200â€“299 range.
